Detailed Description

A simple graphic item.

This is a very simple object, which is rather useless (you can create a basic pushbutton, but not more). It's mostly present to be used as parent by other graphics items classes. This class create a sf::Sprite which represent a graphic item. There are some basic functions to set the general appearance like setBackground. This class can handle some common events which are possibly used by all widgets like clicks, mouse hover...

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

sfgui::Object::Object ( sf::RenderWindow *  parentWindow  ) 

Construct a simple graphic object

Load the default background images

sfgui::Object::Object ( sf::RenderWindow *  parent,
std::string  themePath 
)

Construct a graphic object which uses a custom theme instead of the default one. Instead of changing the theme by SetTheme, it's recomanded to use this constructor, as it directly loads the right images (it avoid loading images twices).

sfgui::Object::~Object (  ) 

Delete all the pointers, free the image map...

Member Function Documentation

void sfgui::Object::SetTheme ( std::string  dir  ) 

Load a background theme from a directory containing the right png images :

  • button.png is the normal background
  • button_clicked.png is the clicked background
  • button_hover.png is the background showed when mouse is above the button

void sfgui::Object::SetBackground ( int  background  ) 

Set a background from an image which is already loaded int this object. Throws : when an error occurs, like image index doesn't exists, it throw a sfgui::Error

Parameters:
background It is the num of the background. It must one of the followings values : Object::BackgroundNormal, Object::BackgroundClicked, Object::BackgroundHover ...
See also:
sfgui::Object::ButtonStates for the complete list of backgrounds values

Set size of the text

float sfgui::Object::GetTextSize (  ) 

void sfgui::Object::SetTextFont ( sf::Font &  font  ) 

Set the text font. Warning : For some inherited widets (such as TextEdit) a non monospaced font will cause problems (like text getting out of the font...). It is because SFML doesn't provide function to get charachter width (so it is based on a constant one, wich is get from one character).

sf::Font sfgui::Object::GetTextFont (  ) 

void sfgui::Object::SetTextAlignment ( int  al  ) 

This set the position of the text on the button. You should use one of the following constant value sfgui::LEFT, sfgui::RIGHT, sfgui::CENTER

void sfgui::Object::SetTextMargin ( float  margin  ) 

Set the global margin. The text will be spaced from the button each border by a number of pixels.

void sfgui::Object::SetTextLeftMargin ( float  margin  ) 

Set the left margin. Text will be spaced from the left border of the button

void sfgui::Object::SetTextRightMargin ( float  margin  ) 

Set the right margin. Text will be spaced form the right border of the button.

set the bottom margin. Text will be spaced from the bottom border of the button

void sfgui::Object::SetPosition ( float  x,
float  y

Call the click callback function. It's automatically called by checkEvent, but you can also call it yourself if needed.

Called when the mouse is above the button

void sfgui::Object::MouseNotHover (  ) 

Called when the mouse is not above the button. It restores the default button theme

void sfgui::Object::updateTextPos (  )  [protected]

This function is called internally when the position of the button is changed, when text changed (...) to adapt the text position so that it stays to the right alignment
